rename.to: Super big l2 norm of dvf gradient

body:
@XXZhou25 Thanks for your comment on voxelmorph

Just to be clear, are you saying that the code you used, `gradientLoss` is the one that worked or the one that didn't ?

> @XXZhou25 Thanks for your comment on voxelmorph
> 
> Just to be clear, are you saying that the code you used, `gradientLoss` is the one that worked or the one that didn't ?

Hi, sorry to probably confused you! The `gradientLoss` I used in voxelmorph, which is `voxelmorph.losses.Grad('l2')` didn't work. Actually I am not sure if it is this loss didn't work. 
More accurately, the combination: `losses = [vxm.losses.NCC().loss, vxm.losses.Grad('l2').loss]` didn't reduce the dvf loss as expected. I got out-of-image displacements. 

Btw, I am also not sure if it is my data's problem. I standardized it before training. It worked fine with my own loss code.
when using `[NCC, Grad]`, what was the learning rate?

> when using `[NCC, Grad]`, what was the learning rate?
It is : 
`    lambda_param = 0.5
    loss_weights = [1, lambda_param]`
I mean the optimizer learning rate -- or did you use the same one that was there by default?

> I mean the optimizer learning rate -- or did you use the same one that was there by default?

Oh I am sorry. Yeah I used Adam, with `lr = 1e-4` . 
Last time I got super large dvf, is caused by MSE + non-normalized data.

Hmm, this seems a bit odd, Are you sure the images are properly normalized?

Could you share a couple of screenshots (with a colorbar) for an example pair of images?
This pair is before standardize. I standardize them after reading original images.

The images seem to contains some machinery at the edges, interesting. I'm not sure what sort of effect this would have.

I'd recommend visualizing data in python -- the moving, fixed, moved, and the warp field (via warping a grid, maybe) with colorbars. That would help debug what is going on.

> The images seem to contains some machinery at the edges, interesting. I'm not sure what sort of effect this would have.
> 
> I'd recommend visualizing data in python -- the moving, fixed, moved, and the warp field (via warping a grid, maybe) with colorbars. That would help debug what is going on.

Thank you very much for your help! May I show you 3D dvf? I may need to look into how to visualize with warping a grid.

> The images seem to contains some machinery at the edges, interesting. I'm not sure what sort of effect this would have.
> 
> I'd recommend visualizing data in python -- the moving, fixed, moved, and the warp field (via warping a grid, maybe) with colorbars. That would help debug what is going on.

Thank you so much for your suggestions! It is quite odd to me, too. It worked fine with MSE or NCC with my own code. I will try to dig more! Thanks for your time!

I would strongly recommend visualizing middle slices them in python after they come from the generator, this would enable you to see what the network actually sees and avoid any bugs.

Have you tried training the NCC model a couple of times? you might've just been unlucky with some bad gradients at the start. Maybe try a slightly smaller learning rate as well.

> I would strongly recommend visualizing middle slices them in python after they come from the generator, this would enable you to see what the network actually sees and avoid any bugs.
> 
> Have you tried training the NCC model a couple of times? you might've just been unlucky with some bad gradients at the start. Maybe try a slightly smaller learning rate as well.

I see. These are good points! Yeah probably data source or bad initialization problem. Will look into it! Thank you very much!

> I would strongly recommend visualizing middle slices them in python after they come from the generator, this would enable you to see what the network actually sees and avoid any bugs.
> 
> Have you tried training the NCC model a couple of times? you might've just been unlucky with some bad gradients at the start. Maybe try a slightly smaller learning rate as well.

Hi @adalca , I just looked into everything about data, generator output, my codes...I was desperate and I just decided to run it again...Magically `gradientLoss` got back to normal right now....still not sure if it is bad initialization, since I thought probably bad, but hard not be as large as thousands. But anyways, good news is that it worked properly now! Thank you very much for your suggestions!
